title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Strengths (S):

Strong foundation in statistics from undergraduate studies (regression, time series, multivariate analysis).

Experience in mathematical modelling competitions and undergraduate dissertation.

Basic programming skills in Python.

Weaknesses (W):

Limited knowledge of healthcare data and informatics.

Weakness in English academic writing and oral presentation.

No prior experience with real-world health datasets (EHR, genomics).

Opportunities (O):

Enrolled in KCL‚Äôs ASMHI MSc programme, providing interdisciplinary training (statistics + informatics + healthcare).

Access to courses and dissertation project to learn advanced methods (causal inference, NLP, genomics).

Career services offering employability training and networking.

Threats (T):

Highly competitive job market for international graduates.

Steep learning curve to adapt to cross-disciplinary content.

Lack of local research or industry background compared to UK peers.

title: SWOT Analysis
section: Course: 7BBG2014 Bioinformatics, Interpretation and Data Quality in Genome Analysis
text:
Course: 7BBG2014 Bioinformatics, Interpretation and Data Quality in Genome Analysis

Strengths (S):

Solid statistical foundation supports understanding of data quality and interpretation.


Weaknesses (W):

Limited background in biology made it challenging to fully grasp the context of genomic data.


Opportunities (O):

Hands-on training in Galaxy platform and Python applications provided practical experience in genomic analysis.


Threats (T):

Complexity and scale of genomic data may hinder future application without continued practice.

title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Course: 7PAVITHI Introduction to Health Informatics

Strengths (S):

Ability to connect statistical concepts with health data management.


Weaknesses (W):

Limited familiarity with healthcare terminologies and standards such as HL7/FHIR.


Opportunities (O):

Built foundation for understanding EHR systems, essential for dissertation research and future career.


Threats (T):

Risk of superficial understanding if statistical and informatics knowledge are not fully integrated.

title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Course: 7PAVITPR Introduction to Statistical Programming

Strengths (S):

Prior exposure to Python accelerated learning in statistical programming.


Weaknesses (W):

Inexperience with R and Stata required additional time to master.


Opportunities (O):

Gained proficiency across multiple programming languages (Python, R, Stata), useful for research and industry.


Threats (T):

Challenge of learning multiple programming paradigms simultaneously created cognitive pressure.

title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Course: 7PAVITSM Introduction to Statistical Modelling

Strengths (S):

Familiarity with regression and modelling from undergraduate background.


Weaknesses (W):

Shallow understanding of diagnostic checks and underlying assumptions.


Opportunities (O):

Course highlighted model interpretation and applications to clinical datasets, relevant for future dissertation.


Threats (T):

Risk of over-focusing on computation without developing deeper critical thinking.

title: SWOT Analysis
section: Course: 7PAVMALE Machine Learning for Health and Bioinformatics
text:
Course: 7PAVMALE Machine Learning for Health and Bioinformatics

Strengths (S):

Prior experience with Python and statistical modelling supported initial understanding of algorithms.

Interest in applying ML methods to biomedical datasets, linking theory to practice.

Weaknesses (W):

Struggled with the final exam, showing that conceptual mastery and coding application were not fully consolidated.

Difficulty balancing theoretical ML concepts (e.g., bias-variance trade-off, hyperparameter tuning) with practical implementation.

Opportunities (O):

Course provided exposure to advanced models (SVM, Random Forest, Neural Networks) in a health context.

Opened pathways to integrating ML into dissertation work, especially for text and EHR data.

Threats (T):

Performance gap in assessment may affect confidence in pursuing ML-heavy projects.

Rapidly evolving ML field requires continuous self-learning beyond course content.

title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Course: 7PAVMALM Multilevel and Longitudinal Modelling

Strengths (S):

Built on existing regression knowledge, with smooth transition into hierarchical and growth-curve models.

Gained hands-on experience in R with lme4/nlme, strengthening programming confidence.

Weaknesses (W):

Interpretation of random effects and model fit statistics required extra study time.

Limited exposure to large-scale longitudinal datasets reduced practice opportunities.

Opportunities (O):

Course directly linked to health applications, providing tools to analyse repeated measures and patient outcomes.

Highly relevant for academic research and potential PhD projects.

Threats (T):

Complexity of multilevel models can lead to misinterpretation if not carefully validated.

Risk of over-reliance on software without critical examination of assumptions.

title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Course: 7PAVNLPS Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Strengths (S):

Directly aligned with dissertation research on NLP and RAG systems, providing immediate methodological support.

Existing experience in Python and text mining facilitated faster adaptation.


Weaknesses (W):

Limited understanding of the theoretical foundations of deep learning models such as Transformer, BERT, and SciBERT.

Lack of extensive hands-on experience with hyperparameter tuning and evaluation.


Opportunities (O):

NLP is a cutting-edge field highly relevant to health informatics, enhancing prospects for PhD applications and career opportunities.

Coursework and dissertation outcomes can be integrated into the ePortfolio and academic presentations.


Threats (T):

The rapid development of NLP poses a risk of knowledge becoming outdated without continuous learning.

Dissertation heavily depends on NLP methods, so insufficient mastery could affect final outcomes.

title: SWOT Analysis
text:
Course: 7PAVCIAE Causal Modelling and Evaluation

Strengths (S):

Strong statistical foundation from undergraduate studies supports causal inference learning.

Acquired practical methods such as Propensity Score Matching (PSM), Inverse Probability of Treatment Weighting (IPTW), and Instrumental Variables (IV).

Confident in implementing models in both Stata and R.


Weaknesses (W):

Deeper understanding still needed for advanced methods (e.g., mediation analysis, dynamic treatment regimes).

Academic writing and logical explanation of causal effects and assumptions require further refinement.


Opportunities (O):

Causal inference has wide applications in health data research and real-world evidence studies.

Highly relevant for future PhD research and industry roles in pharma/health data science.


Threats (T):

Results are highly sensitive to data quality and modelling assumptions; errors can lead to biased conclusions.

Growing demand for causal inference expertise makes the job market increasingly competitive.

title: Seminar Series & Skills Workshops Reflections
text:
Introduction to the ePortfolio and Transition to the MSc (23/09/2024)
Helped me quickly understand the structure and assessment requirements of the ePortfolio, supporting a smooth transition into the MSc.
Reflection, Goal Setting and Action Planning (30/09/2024)
Introduced reflection models (e.g., Gibbs) and SMART goal-setting, which guided my academic and personal planning.
Practical Tools (Quarto and Friends, 14/10/2024)
Provided hands-on training with Quarto, which became the foundation for preparing my ePortfolio and coursework.
Critical Reading and Journal Club (21/10/2024)
Improved my ability to critically analyse academic papers and strengthened oral communication during journal discussions.
Finding and Evaluating Research: Library Services (04/11/2024)
Enhanced my skills in literature search and database use, improving the efficiency of reviews and assignments.
Generative AI (07/11/2024)
Offered a balanced perspective on opportunities and risks of generative AI, guiding my responsible use of AI in research.
Writing Workshop (11/11/2024)
Strengthened my academic writing, particularly in structuring arguments and refining style.
Marketing of Yourself (18/11/2024, rescheduled)
Showed me how to better present my skills and experiences through CVs, cover letters, and interviews.
ePortfolio Workshop (02/12/2024)
Helped me align reflections with evidence and career goals for stronger ePortfolio impact.






Research Project Workshop (13/01/2025)
Supported planning of my dissertation, from research design to data management.
Ethics in Research (20/01/2025)
Reinforced the importance of ethics, data privacy, and research accountability, especially relevant to EHR data.
Reproducibility Crisis (03/02/2025)
Highlighted the importance of transparency and reproducibility, which I applied to my own coding and data management.
ePortfolio Workshop (10/02/2025)
Helped refine my portfolio structure, ensuring coherence between reflections, evidence, and career narrative.
Resilience, Adaptability, Wellness (24/02/2025)
Offered strategies to maintain mental health and adaptability under academic and personal pressure, essential during dissertation writing.
Ethics in AI (24/03/2025)
Explored fairness, bias, and responsibility in AI applications, directly relevant to my NLP + EHR research project.






Interview Skills (12/05/2025)
Improved my ability to answer both technical and behavioural questions confidently.
Posters and Presentations (02/06/2025)
Provided practical guidance on poster and presentation design, directly supporting my MSc Poster Showcase.
ePortfolio Workshop (16/06/2025)
Clarified submission requirements and helped finalise layout and reflective writing.
Cultural Competency in Research (30/06/2025)
Emphasised cultural sensitivity in research design and interpretation, making me more aware of diversity issues in health data.






Learning: Strengthened my academic writing, literature reading, and technical skills, enhancing both efficiency and outcomes.

Employability: Improved my CV, interview techniques, and career planning, building confidence in job applications.

Research: Ethics and AI seminars shaped my dissertation approach, ensuring that my RAG system design accounted for compliance and social responsibility.

text:
Short-Term (6‚Äì12 months)

Complete my dissertation and MSc degree successfully.

Apply for data analysis, health-tech, or pharmaceutical roles to gain practical experience.

Strengthen my academic writing and research communication skills.

title: MSc ePortfolio
text:
Mid-Term (1‚Äì2 years)

Gain professional experience in health informatics or Real-World Evidence (RWE) research.

Lead independent projects in data analysis or health research.

text:
Long-Term (2‚Äì5 years)

Explore interdisciplinary research bridging AI technologies and clinical practice.

title: Portfolio of Evidence
text:
This section showcases four representative academic outputs from my MSc journey, covering research, coursework, and causal inference analysis. Together, they highlight my core competencies in health informatics, NLP, causal inference, and multilevel modelling.




Topic: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system for Electronic Health Records (EHR)

Outcome: Built a clinical Q&A system on the MIMIC-IV dataset (14,000+ patients), achieving ~60% accuracy.

Highlights: Integrated MiniLM embeddings, Chroma/FAISS vector databases, and LangChain pipelines; developed interactive interfaces for query and summarisation.

File: üìÑ View Poster PDF






Topic: Natural Language Processing and Deep Learning applied to clinical text

Outcome: Completed coursework exploring Transformer/BERT models for medical text classification and information extraction.

Highlights: Implemented preprocessing, model training, and evaluation, demonstrating the applicability of NLP to healthcare data.

File: üìÑ View NLP Report PDF





Topic: Survival analysis within multilevel and longitudinal modelling

Outcome: Applied survival analysis techniques in R to model time-to-event outcomes in health data.

Highlights: Implemented Cox proportional hazards models and extensions, explored stratification and covariate effects, and interpreted survival curves in a health informatics context.

File: üìÑ View Multilevel Report PDF






Topic: Application of machine learning methods to health and genomic datasets

Outcome: Explored supervised and unsupervised ML approaches for patient data classification and feature selection.

Highlights: Implemented algorithms such as Random Forests, Support Vector Machines, and Neural Networks to evaluate predictive performance.

Reflection: While my exam performance was weaker than expected, the coursework significantly strengthened my coding skills and deepened my understanding of model evaluation and reproducibility.

File: üìÑ View Coding

title: Career Readiness Reflection
text:
During my MSc studies, I gradually refined my career direction: from an initial focus on statistical analyst roles to health data science, real-world evidence (RWE) research, and AI applications in healthcare.

Through coursework and dissertation work, I developed strong interdisciplinary skills (statistical modelling √ó NLP √ó health informatics), which form a solid foundation for future opportunities.

I am considering two possible pathways:

PhD Research ‚Äì pursuing advanced study in the intersection of causal inference, NLP, and health data.

Industry Employment ‚Äì applying for roles in pharmaceutical companies, healthcare AI firms, or health data analysis teams.







I have begun preparing application materials for industry roles, with multiple revisions of my Master CV and personal statement.

From Careers Workshop mock interviews, I received constructive feedback:

Strengths: Research experience and interdisciplinary background are clear assets; technical skills (Python, R, Stata) are well demonstrated in applied contexts.

Areas to Improve: Need to articulate career goals more clearly during interviews, and explicitly link project outcomes to role requirements.


While I have not yet secured a formal interview, the practice sessions and feedback have increased my confidence in self-presentation.






Attended Careers Service CV and cover letter workshops, receiving personalised advice.

Participated in King‚Äôs Edge Employability sessions, which enhanced my understanding of networking and career planning.

Used the Careers Connect platform to search and apply for positions in health data science and RWE.






Academic Path: If pursuing a PhD, I need to strengthen my research proposal writing and academic communication skills.

Industry Path: For professional roles, I plan to build additional GitHub projects and case studies to showcase technical applications.

Soft Skills: Continue improving self-presentation and communication in interview and networking contexts.

title: Action Plan
text:
Academic Development: Completed the majority of MSc modules, gaining knowledge in causal modelling, multilevel modelling, NLP, and machine learning for health data. Dissertation (RAG-based Clinical QA System for EHRs) has reached the stage of completed experiments and analysis.

Skills Growth: Significantly improved proficiency in Python, R, and Stata; built cross-disciplinary analytical abilities.

Career Preparation: Refined Master CV through multiple iterations, attended Careers Workshops and mock interviews, strengthening professional positioning and self-presentation.

Networking: Established initial connections with industry mentors through university events, receiving practical career advice.

text:

title: Action Plan
text:
üîÑ What Has Changed

Research Interests: Initially focused on traditional statistical modelling, but shifted towards NLP + causal inference + health data through dissertation research.

Career Direction: Early career goals were more aligned with statistical analyst roles; now increasingly oriented toward health data science, real-world evidence (RWE), and AI in healthcare/pharma.

Skills Gaps Identified: Recognised the need to improve academic writing and deep learning model optimisation through coursework and dissertation practice.

Time Planning: Originally adopted a flexible application schedule, but with graduation approaching, greater urgency and efficiency are required.

title: Action Plan
text:
üöÄ Next Steps

Short-Term Goals (Next 6 Months, pre-graduation):

Finalise and submit MSc dissertation; prepare to adapt results into a publishable academic paper.

Develop 2‚Äì3 showcase GitHub projects focusing on NLP and causal inference as part of a professional portfolio.

Mid-Term Goals (Within 1 Year post-graduation):

Apply for roles in the UK or China in health data science, RWE research, or AI-driven healthcare companies, gaining industry experience.

Attend academic conferences or workshops to expand professional and research networks.

Strengthen deep learning and academic writing skills to address current weaknesses.

Long-Term Goals (3‚Äì5 Years):

After building industry experience, pursue a PhD focusing on Causal Inference √ó NLP √ó Health Data.

Develop an interdisciplinary professional profile that bridges academic research and applied practice in health informatics.

title: Curriculum Vitae
text:
‚ú® Summary Statement
A Master‚Äôs graduate in Applied Statistical Modelling & Health Informatics at King‚Äôs College London, with strong skills in data analysis, machine learning, and causal inference. Experienced in working with large-scale healthcare datasets (MIMIC-IV, 14k+ patients) and building Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) NLP systems for clinical information retrieval. Skilled in Python, R, and Stata, with internship experience in customer data analysis and business intelligence. Seeking opportunities in the pharmaceutical or health-tech sector to apply advanced analytics and AI to real-world healthcare challenges.

title: Final Reflective Piece
text:
Looking back on this MSc journey, I would tell my past self:
- Stay open-minded: Do not fear unfamiliar domains; growth often comes from moments of discomfort.
- Embrace mistakes: Errors in experiments, code failures, and missteps are not setbacks but essential steps in learning.
- Learn to prioritise: It is not possible to do everything perfectly‚Äîfocus on the core objectives and keep momentum.
- Seek support proactively: Supervisors, peers, and career services are invaluable sources of guidance at critical points.





Depth of reflection: At the beginning, I was focused only on completing tasks; later, I realised that reflection itself is a powerful tool for learning and growth.

Scientific storytelling: Beyond results, it is crucial to communicate why the research matters, how it was done, and what impact it brings.

Interdisciplinary language: The ability to communicate across statisticians, computer scientists, and clinicians is essential, translating complex concepts for different audiences.

Long-term vision: Initially, I concentrated on immediate tasks, but gradually I learned to connect my academic development with my professional trajectory.






Personal: I want to sustain curiosity and intrinsic motivation, continuing to find my place in the fast-evolving intersection of AI and health data.

Professional: Whether entering industry or pursuing a PhD, my goal is not just to be someone who can code and model, but someone who can ask meaningful questions and help deliver practical solutions.

Long-term vision: In the next 5‚Äì10 years, I aspire to become a bridge between academic research and clinical application, ensuring that technology meaningfully serves healthcare and public health.

title: Research Project Reflection
text:
Note



Chosen Reflective Model: Gibbs Reflective Cycle
Reason: This model clearly follows the structure What happened ‚Üí So what ‚Üí Now what, which helps me to systematically analyse experiences and link them to SMART action planning.

title: Research Project Reflection
text:
üìå Project Summary
My MSc dissertation project focuses on the Application of Large Language Models (LLMs) for Electronic Health Records summarisation and patient search.
The objective was to build a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) clinical Q&A system for patient record summarisation and information retrieval.

Methods

Used MiniLM embeddings to vectorise clinical notes.

Applied Chroma/FAISS vector databases for similarity search.

Built the full RAG pipeline with LangChain, including document chunking, embedding, retriever, reranker, and generation.

Developed interactive interfaces with Streamlit and Gradio to simulate clinical information retrieval scenarios.

Evaluated performance on the EHRNoteQA dataset using Accuracy, F1, and RAGAS metrics.

Outcomes

Achieved ~60% accuracy on the MIMIC-IV dataset (14,000+ patients).

Demonstrated the feasibility of RAG for EHR-based summarisation and clinical Q&A.

Established a baseline for future improvements (e.g., reranker integration, knowledge graph, multimodal data).

My Contribution
I independently handled the entire pipeline: data preprocessing, system design, evaluation, and interface development.
This process significantly enhanced my technical, analytical, and research skills.

title: Research Project Reflection
text:
üå± Skills Development

Project Management: Planned milestones and balanced dissertation, coursework, and personal commitments.

Data Engineering: Learned EHR text preprocessing, semantic chunking, embedding generation, and database optimisation.

Programming & Tools: Proficient with Python, LangChain, FAISS/Chroma, Streamlit, and Gradio.

Research Skills: Critically evaluated model outputs and compared different evaluation metrics.

Academic Communication: Presented results in poster sessions and supervisory meetings with clarity.

Critical Thinking: Reflected not only on performance metrics but also on clinical usability and applicability.

title: Research Project Reflection
text:
‚ö° Challenges and Solutions

Technical: Large embedding batches caused memory issues.
Solution: Applied batch embedding, semantic chunking, and optimised Chroma indexing.
Data: Long EHR texts contained redundancy and noise, lowering retrieval precision.
Solution: Designed semantic chunking strategies and added a Cohere reranker.
Evaluation: Accuracy, F1, BLEU, and RAGAS gave inconsistent conclusions.
Solution: Adopted a multi-dimensional evaluation framework with quantitative + qualitative analysis.
Time Pressure: Balancing coursework and dissertation.
Solution: Used weekly task lists and a Kanban tool to monitor milestones.

title: Research Project Reflection
text:
üí° Reflection and Growth

Experience: System design should align with real-world needs rather than chasing metrics alone.

Growth: Transitioned from unfamiliarity with RAG to independently building and evaluating a full pipeline.

Improvement Needed: More rigorous experimental design (control groups, statistical tests); stronger academic writing structure.

title: Research Project Reflection
text:
üöÄ SMART Next Steps

Specific: Integrate a stronger reranker and lightweight knowledge graph; include structured data (labs, prescriptions).

Measurable: Improve accuracy to ‚â•70%, raise F1 by ‚â•10%, and achieve higher RAGAS (Faithfulness, Answer Relevance).

Achievable: Build on existing LangChain + Cohere toolchain; iterate with small-scale experiments.

Relevant: Aligned with my career and research pathway in Health Informatics √ó NLP.

Time-bound: Complete improvements and a draft publication by December 2025.

title: Skills Mapping
text:

- Time Management: Balanced coursework, dissertation research, and personal life, ensuring all tasks were delivered on time.
- Resilience: Maintained motivation when facing cross-disciplinary challenges (statistics, informatics, causal inference, genomics).
- Adaptability: Transitioned smoothly from an undergraduate degree in statistics to an MSc in health informatics, quickly learning about EHRs, RAG, and causal inference.
- Leadership: Acted as coordinator and presenter in group projects, responsible for task allocation, timeline tracking, and integrating outputs.
